newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: SOCCER-UEFA TO INVESTIGATE PORTO CUP BATTLE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-UEFA TO INVESTIGATE PORTO CUP BATTLE.

text.p: UEFA said on Thursday it would look into the clash that left eight Manchester United fans injured after a run-in with anti-riot police following Wednesday's European Cup quarter-final against Porto.
The incident will top the agenda at the UEFA's regularly scheduled Control and Disciplinary committee meeting next Tuesday in Nyon.
UEFA spokesman Frits Alstrom said the committee could impose immediate sanctions after reviewing reports from the police, referee and official delegate, Des Casey.
"There could be sanctions taken right away but we will have to see the report first," said Alstrom. "We will have to see if what happened is a UEFA matter.
"What happened outside the stadium is not always a UEFA responsibility unless it has something to do with security or some other related issue."
The problems began as some United fans tried to leave the stadium shortly before the end of the game, ignoring official instructions to stay put.
Oporto police chief Delfim Passos said his men fired plastic pellets and small rubber balls -- both part of anti-riot equipment -- to contain United fans seeking to break out of the stadium.
The injured, including one fan with head wounds, were taken to hospital but all were discharged in the early hours of Thursday, British consular officials said.
The match ended 0-0 but Manchester United went through 4-0 on aggregate after trouncing Porto at Old Trafford.
